messages.content:
You are a teacher to a 7th Grade class. Your students have been told to write a Persuasive/Narrative/Expository essay about the following prompt: 'Write about patience. Being patient means that you are understanding and tolerant. A patient person experience difficulties without complaining. Do only one of the following: write a story about a time when you were patient OR write a story about a time when someone you know was patient OR write a story in your own way about patience.' 

You are tasked with generating a short paragraph of feedback relating to 1 of 6 main categories: 
1. Ideas (Tells a story with ideas that are clearly focused on the topic and are thoroughly developed with specific, relevant details.) 
2. Organization (Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are clear and logically sequenced.) 
3. Style (Command of language, including effective and compelling word choice and varied sentence structure, clearly supports the writer's purpose and audience.) 
4. Conventions (Consistent, appropriate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.) 

The feedback paragraphs should generally be 2-3 sentences long and should have a formal and professional tone. They should be able to be clearly understood by a student in Grade 7.

Essay: 'My cosine went and find out away to find out and it is a fourwheer. He had went 4 momts for it. So he batd for a monts so he get it ruel.' 
Category: Ideas 
Score: 0
In this brief response, patience is expressed by waiting (he had to wait 4 months). However, the idea is undeveloped.

Essay: 'Helllow my name is Phil and this is a story about my friend not being patient. It all stord two weeks a go I was baby siting my bater and my siter was at her kogfow class and my dad was sleeping. Now my batter is prity macher, and he can usloe do very thing him slef, but he is big gofe ball, he is 11 yers old and, he is cool some times. My siter is the bigst brat ever, she never soes what she told, she Does not get her way she cry's and, She louck's her Shelf in her room, She tlack's like shE is two, me, my bater, and my dad said we can't under stand her, She has a highe schkey vioce thrt souds like rusty nailes on 3000 chake bord some times I scoop out eyes with a spoun, and cut of my eres with a kife, so don't have to see or here her. So any way I was siting I the coch whin I herd a knock of the door it was my frind Sam he is ok he whant to play Foot Ball I said ok asked my dad and wint in the back yared. The ball Got stuck in the gaten I whint up and got it and trow it down on so let me get down he siad OK I was adout to get down then he rushed me off then Side took to long I Fell and brok my foot. Well thats my story see you next year.' 
Category: Ideas 
Score: 1
In this lengthy response, the ideas are minimally focused on patience with few details; other information is irrelevant.

Essay: 'I can still remember wene I was pashint for the ferst time. it was a long time agowe wene I was lost in the Woods. At ferst I was vary scard and herd a lote of noyses but I stad callm and paishent. About an oher later I herd sumthing cuming throu the woods so I hid in the Fallsleevs. But it ternd out to be my mom. She touk me back to the house and I toold her about how I was pashent tly waiting for her. And that was one time I was pashent.' 
Category: Ideas 
Score: 1
This brief response has ideas that are somewhat focused on patience and includes a mix of general (I heard a lot of noises) and specific (I hid in the fall leaves) details.

Essay: 'I'm not very good at being patient, but my mom is. Even if I'm mean to my brothers she stays patient with me, or if I eat too much food, or, nevermind, but my mom always wonderfully patient.  
My mom usually keeps a cool head if I do something wrong (the key word is usually), like if I hurt myself, can't choose anything to wear, things like that. Believe me, I've had my fair share of those actions. Once, I was running on the track at my elementary school, and I tripped over my humongous feet. I slammed into the cement and slid about two feet. By the time a teacher got over to me, I was bleeding and blubbering my head off. They fixed me up pretty good, but it was hard since both my hands, both my knees, and both my elbows were bleeding. The secretary called my mom and told her what happened. Sure my mom lost her head for a moment, but in the end, she was extremely patient when she had to change my bandaids, give me Benedryl, and all that good stuff. 
There's been plenty of times my mom has been patient with me, like when I broke the VCR player a little while ago. I really don't know how I did it, but I managed to get a VCR tape stuck in the player. Evidently, I somehow got the tape stuck between something in the machine. It's really complicated, so I don't want to go into it. This time, both my mom and my dad had to be patient with me. My dad stopped being patient when he had to unplug the VCR player, take it apart, and pry the tape out. By the time all this was over, my parents had forgiven me, and the VCR is still working. 
I'm really glad my mom stayed patient with me through thick and thin. If she hadn't, I'd be awreck right now. An orphan, crawling on the streets begging for a scrap of food, okay, that's a slight exaggeration, fine, a big one, but I'm still glad my mom stayed patient with me. That's why I love her so much.' 
Category: Ideas 
Score: 2

This longer response contains two stories that are somewhat focused on patience and are developed with some specific details (I tripped over my humongous feet, she had to change my band-aids, give me benadryl, pry the tape out).

Essay: 'I don't have patients at all. I can tell you how. It was a bright sunny day the sun was bright the grass was swaying back in forth with the wind in the feld. I was on my way to Melissa's house and I was waiting for my mom to bring me because I did not fell like walking. I got into the car, but my mom was still in the I mean go figure she was slow than the titance at full speed! I was waiting patiently but the clock keep ticking minute after minute. I said in my what was taking my mom so long? So since I don't have any patients I got out of the slamed the door like I was throwing a tomatoe at my sister and stormed inside like a herd of animals! I yelled "What is taking you so long mom?" Come to find out she was talking on the phone to my Aunt Sue. I said to myself once again this is going to take forever I could have walked from Melissa's house and back five times now! 
While I was sitting on the couch waiting for my mom to get off the phone I tuned on the t.V, but of corse nothin good was on because we did not have HD or cable like my other friends did. So basicaly I was slipping through the five same channels over and over again. I turn off the t.v. got up went back into the car turned on the radio and looked out the window STILL waiting for my mom. Man was I getting mad. So I honked the horn over and over again. Then finnly my mom got off her lasy but said good bye to Aunt Sue and came to the car. But it did not go any faster she drove twenty on a forty miles per hour road so it took us almost ten minutes to get there when originaly it really takes five minuets. 
When she finnley got to Melissa's house I ran out a Yelled....
"I'll call you when to pick me up!" Then she said okay and drove off. Man was I glad not to be with her after that.' 
Category: Ideas 
Score: 3

Ideas in this longer response are clearly focused on patience (waiting for a ride to a friend's house) and thoroughly developed with specific, relevant details (I slammed the door, flipping through the same 5 channels, she drove 20 on a 40 mph road).

Essay: 'I remember the time when I was not patient. It was early this month when I found out that we had the halloween dance coming up. So I spent alot of time trying to find a costume for the dance. I went halloween crazy. I had lost my patience. My brain felt like it was running around screaming "AAAAH! SOMEONE, HELP ME!! My friend Emily Smith said "you can't have a dance without a date." Thats what my brain is freaked out about. a date to the dance. Right now that's all I'm worried about. I had just got a costume last weekend, it's called a "punk witch." It is a sleeveless black dress, with a (attached) red skirt -> <- on the dress is a skull and crossbones witn a red bow and the picture (the skull and crossbones) is made out of sequins. There is a cape a witch's hat and fishnet tights. So now, I don't have ANY patience left. Now thats only because I just can't wait until the dance but, I'm nervous. help me!' 
Category: Organization 
Score: 1
The organization of the ideas in this response is weak and not logically sequenced (trying to find a costume for the dance, you can't have a dance without a date, I had just got a costume).

Essay: 'It was a horrible, terrible and devistating time of patience. Every bit of it was terror. When I was about nine I rember an accident in my life and remember it all to well. The day of my accident it was beautiful out and my brother and I decided to take our four wheelers out for a ride. That was the worst decision of my life. It caused to much pain and suffering. 
My four wheeler accident was terrible as you know, but this is how it happend. I was riding on a beautiful day. I was heading down the road behind my brother on our four wheelers when it happened, My helmet fogged up and started to swerve back and forth, back and forth. I couldn't see, I had to lift the shield, but it was too late. I had been swung in to a dich and my four wheeler's throttle had stuck. In all this My right leg had been dragged up against a barbwire fence. Rusty old barbwire. It was shreding my leg every second. My scream was horrendus. finally my four wheeler swerved off the road and did a wheelie and I had fallen off and gotten knocked out cold on the ground bleeding. 
My dad picked me up and put me in his truck. Patience, was the theme at that point. An ambulance needs to come. Patience, patience, patience. All of the sudden I glanced down and saw wite bone. I had a chill. Then an ambulance came around the corner and the wait was over. But when I got to the hospital my mother, my sweet loving mother was there in the waiting room. Patience, patience, patience. Two and a half hours later I went to my hospital room and my mom was waiting patiently. 
Some might think this dread may never end, but in time everyone's problems fade... Slowly, slowly, slowly. Still the scars remain heart, soul, mind, and body.' 
Category: Organization 
Score: 2

In this longer response, the organization of ideas and events is logically sequenced. However, the repetition of some ideas from the introduction (terrible accident, beautiful day, riding with my brother) prevents a higher score for this trait.

Essay: 'There was a time when I was not patient. As sad as this is; it was on Christmas. 
It all started a few Christmas' ago. I am not sure how long ago it was, but I have to say it was a few years ago. You see, my family has this rule that we are not allowed to open presents til seven o'clock. This rule is easy to uphold, usually, though instead of waking up at my normal six-thirty, I woke up and it was four-fifteen! 
Just like any little kid on Christmas, my first thought was to sneek downstairs and try to figure out what was in my presents. I knew better, though, I knew that if I was to sneek down to try to figure out my presents I would get in trouble. That was not how I wanted to spend my Christmas, so I decided to read, play with toys, and color to pass the time. 
The minutes went by none to fast. Every minute felt like a hour, every hour felt like a decade! It reminded me of those movies where time would slow down and sometimes even stop. 
As time wore on, the thought to sneek and take a peek at my presents sounded ever more apealing. Several more minutes wore by... at that moment. I decided enough was enough! So, I did something that I would regret later. I snuck down stairs! 
It was not hard. In seconds I was at the Christmas tree. I went to grab my first present when suddenly I acsententally hit a big present that made a loud noise! Emmedially my mom awoke to find me red handed! 
As a result to my actions, my family was not allowed to open presents til eight o'clock! It makes me now think that when someone is not patient, it is like they are acting selfish and only thinking about themselves. 
Now I know it means to be patient. Thinking back makes me believe that if I would have been patient enough to wait til seven o'clock, I would have been able to open my Christmas presents faster.' 
Category: Organization 
Score: 3
In this response, the connections between the ideas are clear and logically sequenced, consistently tied together by transitions that help the response progress throughout.

Essay: 'I remember one time when I was not patient. It was when my brother was playing his Play station, and I really wanted to watch tv. Now, in my house we have this thing that we do: If we have the tv first, then we get up to leave, we get to have the tv back when we return. So anyways, I left for about two minutes and he took the tv away from me. I got very unpatient and annoyed when he said he wouldn't give it back. So, I starting hitting him and throwing stuff at him, thinking that would get him to let me have it. But, he didn't. He just started calling me names, so I ran upstairs to my mom and told her what happened. He was the one who ended up getting in trouble. 
That was quite a while ago when it happened. So, I am much older now, and more patient with people. Oh yeah, and I don't throw tantrums either.' 
Category: Style 
Score: 2
This response contains clear sentences and variety in sentence structure, as well as effective word choice indicating an adequate command of language.

Essay: 'I can't Be patient! Well I mean I can But the exsitement is just to great for me to control myself. Okay Jeremy slow down Breath... Let me start from the begining. This maddness all started when My mom was driving me to my friend Will's house for band pratice. My mom Brought up the conversation about Christmas this year, she asked me if I still Believed in Santa Claus and I replied no. So then she go's on talking about this christmas is gonna be diffrent for me this year. 
I started thinking to myself and had remeberd what my sister told me a few year's ago. Se said that sence she was twelve Mom and Dad would start giving her something much More valuable than toy. Something we all need to survive, They started giving her money! Aproxemently $100.00, Do you know what a twelve year old Boy of my caliber can do with a $100.00? Oh, This christmas is gonna Be sweet. 
I've got it all figured out. I was thinking so hard that my mom had to shake me violently to get me out of my money industed trance. Through out all of Band practice I war Thinking about what I was gonna spend my money on. Until Will told that his Birthday was coming up and He was gonna spend some of his money on his warhammer Army. And that's when it hit me. 
"That's it Will" I yelled 
Will had a confused look on his face and responded 
"What?" 
That's the Answer to my problem, my Army. In the summer time my father Bought me a Army Building force from the game called Warhammer fourty thousand. I assembeld all the piece's a forgot about it when Will mentchend his army my mind suddently Bursted open with Idea's possibility's and a lot of other stuff. After Band practice I raced home and jumped onto my computer. I looked up my army's product List and when I saw the Prices my mind raced. I narrowed the LIst to three Item's AB35 Broadside Mech, A Commander Shadow Sim Mech witch was $25, And a Sniper Drone Squd witch was $30. Oh yes, I've got it all planned out, the fealling is like going up the first hill on a roller coster that sence of antisapation it's hitting me hard. I can't wait for Christmas.'

Essay: 'There was a time when I was not patient. As sad as this is; it was on Christmas. 
It all started a few Christmas' ago. I am not sure how long ago it was, but I have to say it was a few years ago. You see, my family has this rule that we are not allowed to open presents til seven o'clock. This rule is easy to uphold, usually, though instead of waking up at my normal six-thirty, I woke up and it was four-fifteen! 
Just like any little kid on Christmas, my first thought was to sneek downstairs and try to figure out what was in my presents. I knew better, though, I knew that if I was to sneek down to try to figure out my presents I would get in trouble. That was not how I wanted to spend my Christmas, so I decided to read, play with toys, and color to pass the time. 
The minutes went by none to fast. Every minute felt like a hour, every hour felt like a decade! It reminded me of those movies where time would slow down and sometimes even stop. 
As time wore on, the thought to sneek and take a peek at my presents sounded ever more apealing. Several more minutes wore by... at that moment. I decided enough was enough! So, I did something that I would regret later. I snuck down stairs! 
It was not hard. In seconds I was at the Christmas tree. I went to grab my first present when suddenly I acsententally hit a big present that made a loud noise! Emmedially my mom awoke to find me red handed! 
As a result to my actions, my family was not allowed to open presents til eight o'clock! It makes me now think that when someone is not patient, it is like they are acting selfish and only thinking about themselves. 
Now I know it means to be patient. Thinking back makes me believe that if I would have been patient enough to wait til seven o'clock, I would have been able to open my Christmas presents faster.' 
Category: Conventions 
Score: 3
This lengthy response contains one comma-splice error and a few minor spelling errors but otherwise demonstrates consistent, appropriate use of conventions for the grade level.
